review_blob:
Appearance is a nice Amber with a thin head that doesnt go away
Smell is somewhat citrus, caramel, caramel malt, 
Taste is very warm/alcoholic, brown sugar, lingering piney bitterness
Palate is medium-full body with medium carb that is creamy
Overall its a good beer, a sipper, and a little hard to get a read on. Maybe its because I just brushed my teeth

tart/fruity with little toast on the nose; cloudy orange with awesome head retention and great lacing; classic brett tartness with belgian yeast battling for the prominent flavor, orange, ; medium body, good carb, sweeter finish.
Nothing super special. Not a lot of wheat, a little bit of citrus/nose, but bready/yeasty just like their other ales. It leave you with an underwhelming finish asking for something more
lots of orange, nice malt with some caramel, good summer beer, ood carbonation, easy drinking

Lots of Roast and a little peanut on the nose; black with thin tan head, tastes of light roast, subtle PB; Velvety thick mouthfeel and sweet finish; Good but subtle flavors all over, needs a little bit more PB
beer_name: Spiteful God Damn Pirate Pigeon Peanut Butter Porter

review_blob:
Aroma: Very mellow with a little bit of saison yeast imparted. 

Appearance: Perfect yellow color with a bit of haze and a huge white fluffy head that stays the whole way through, lacing the entire way

Taste: Sweet and Tart on the tongue, Spicy and Dry, raisins or dried fruit

Palate: Nice and dry but the fruits pair well with it, lots of carbonation as well

Overall: Awesome example of a saison that comes through with a lot of great yet subtle flavors that make it an easy 5% to enjoy.

12oz bottle into a Tulip
Aroma: Bready Malt and Citrus with a hint of true Orange
Taste: Little citrus upfront, a lot of resin and bitterness at the end, little bits of bready malt, Had to really search to get the fruity and Orange aspects of the beer that it is named after
Palate: Light to medium with good card, no complaints.
Appearence: Dark yellow with particles in it, probably tangerine pith, little cloudy and a little head
Overall: Way too bitter and too much piney resin to be a Session IPA. If you want something like this but a better example, try the calling IPA by Boulevard.

Aroma: Wheat a little clove, not much there
Appearance: Amber in color and thin white head
Taste: very much wheat forward with a little sour/tartness in it, kinda different for a hefe
Palate: Nice dry finish, thin body
Overall: Solid Wheat, more towards American style wheat, different than some wheats with the tartness. Easy Drinking for hot days
beer_name: Public House Hide and Seek Hefeweizen

review_blob: Drink this if you want to know what a citrusy IPA should taste like. Absolutely on point.

Aroma had agave on the nose first followed by wheat
Appearance was cloudy amber, kinda darker than a a typical wheat, maybe due to the agave
Taste was sweet wort with somewhat of a wheat
Palate: mouthfeel was thin and decently carbonated but an awfully sweet finish, needs a more attenuating yeast or something
Overall: very meh. Not bad but certainly one of the lesser wheats I have ever had.

Solid ipa, cant go wrong with it. Definitely a nice go to at a restaurant and such. Great aroma with some citrus and floral coming through. Perfect amount of bitterness for an easy drinking ipa. Great hop flavor with a crisp finish.

12oz bottles at mercadito in River North in Chicago (great contemporary Mexican). Nothing tremendously special. Dark roasts notes with some earthy/piney hops. Really thin body. Interesting but once was enough.

12 oz pour at watershed in Chicago. Wonderful aroma of pine hops and roasted malt. Tasted fantastic with the same taste as was the aroma with a full bodied mouthfeel. Would definitely, and will drink again.

Aroma of caramel, little roasted maybe malt with a great caramel taste in the beginning follows by some warmth of the alcohol an finished with the pinney hops but sweet finish. 

Very well rounded in my opinion.
